steps.title: Listen for squealing sounds from the engine when you drive.
steps.content: Listen for squealing sounds from the engine when you drive. These sounds likely mean one or more belts are worn, loose or damaged.

steps.title: Check belts for signs of wear.
steps.content: Check belts for signs of wear. You need to do more than just visually inspect the belts. Pinch, squeeze and twist them, looking for cracks, fraying, splits or brittle places. [1] X Trustworthy Source Consumer Reports Nonprofit organization dedicated to consumer advocacy and product testing Go to source On a serpentine belt, also look for missing grooves or places where the belt's layers have separated.

steps.title: Check your belts for places where the rubber is slick or glazed in appearance.
steps.content: Check your belts for places where the rubber is slick or glazed in appearance. Slick spots can cause a belt to slip and may be precursors to overheating and cracking.

steps.title: Inspect the pulleys.
steps.content: Inspect the pulleys. Look for a buildup of rubber deposits, as well as worn spots that could catch the belt and cause it to break. [2] X Research source Also check the belts' alignment on the pulleys. They should line up straight on the pulleys.

steps.title: Check the belt tension.
steps.content: Check the belt tension. Check the tension on the longest length of the belt; there should be no more than one-half to one inch (1.25 centimeters to 2.5 centimeters) of give. [3] X Research source
